I think far too many people are
listening to Lo-Fi headphones--

2931.61.text:
little white things
stuck in their ears.

2937.72.text:
But it's just there is a
difference in the hearing

2947.08.text:
But I will always check to make
sure there are no surprises.

2953.71.text:
I mean, headphones
tend accentuate reverb.

2961.02.text:
I find sometimes that I might
back off reverb a little bit

2971.61.text:
I can't do a mix
especially for headphones.

2976.62.text:
of Mystery and
Imagination" was recorded

2984.50.text:
That sounds good on
headphones doesn't it?

2986.79.text:
AUDIENCE: Are there any plans
to release the Alan Parson's

2991.40.text:
Like maybe give them the
King Crimson treatments

2996.13.text:
ALAN PARSONS: I would
like to see that happen.

2999.40.text:
I'm sort of in the
midst of a renegotiation

3002.55.text: with my label and my publisher.

3005.15.text:
So as soon as we
get through that,

3007.22.text:
I'm going to try and get some
high def downloads available.

3013.59.text:
And if no one takes them
up, I'll take them myself.

3022.08.text: We have just a minute left.

3023.56.text:
Is there one final
question that people have?

3026.11.text:
AUDIENCE: You have a
little chapter on MIDI,

3028.00.text:
but I noticed you didn't
have like the little charts

3031.74.text: So how much are you into MIDI?

3035.07.text:
Some people think of it
as an ancient technology,

3037.11.text: but I think it's like WAVs.

3038.41.text:
It actually is pretty
smart and still being used.

3042.01.text:
ALAN PARSONS: Julian
is the MIDI man.

3044.13.text:
JULIAN COLBECK: I
think I actually

3044.76.text:
did write the
first book on MIDI.

3050.42.text: It's a means to an end.

3055.44.text:
I mean, MIDI doesn't
sound good or bad.

3060.12.text:
In good hands, I mean, MIDI
is just unbelievably powerful

3065.44.text:
And it's still there
in kind of version 1.0.

3067.83.text:
I mean there is threatening
things happening at the moment,

3071.06.text:
but essentially it's still
there in its original format.

3073.88.text:
ALAN PARSONS: We can't say that
for much software out there.

3077.59.text:
1983 to now and it
hasn't changed at all.

3084.35.text:
It's kind of difficult
to get your head around,

3086.97.text:
so I think MIDI's problem
is being that people either

3090.71.text:
misinterpret it or don't
use it because they

3092.91.text: are kind of befuddled by it.

3094.74.text:
AUDIENCE: Well, if
you have the ear,

3096.93.text:
you could do a track
that is super solid

3098.60.text: and drag the snare a little bit.

3102.44.text:
AUDIENCE: Stuff that you
couldn't get that drummer

3104.33.text:
ALAN PARSONS: I don't see
that as being a MIDI thing,

3106.54.text: I see that as being a DAW thing.

3110.40.text:
JULIAN COLBECK: Well, I
developed some software

3113.36.text:
Twiddly.Bits which
are these little what

3119.23.text:
And these were MIDI recordings
of drummers and bass players

3121.94.text:
and guitar players using MIDI
drums, MIDI bass, MIDI guitars.

3126.08.text:
And one of the
things we did early,

3127.75.text:
I was playing with Bill Bruford,
from King Crimson and YES,

3132.63.text:
and we recorded him on a Simmons
kit-- a sophisticated STX kit.

3139.25.text:
And Bill sounds like Bill on any
kit you care to name in MIDI.

3143.68.text: You can just feel his heartbeat.

3145.36.text:
He's always slightly
ahead on the snare,

3147.24.text:
slightly behind
on the kick drum.

3149.81.text:
So, I mean, MIDI I
think has the capability

3152.64.text:
of displaying your DNA as
a player, as a performer.

3159.46.text:
ALAN PARSONS: And it
still forms the basis

3162.33.text:
of so much more than just
keyboards and samples.

3169.15.text:
Mixing automation is
based on MIDI largely.

3174.14.text:
My console at home
it uses MIDI to talk

3179.86.text:
to other components
in the system.

3183.79.text:
So it's not all about
punching notes onto a screen

3189.46.text:
or telling one keyboard
to play another keyboard.

3202.27.text:
All right, everybody,
let's thank Alan and Julian
